channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Smog Chokes Delhi, Leaving Residents ‘Cowering by Our Air Purifiers’
item.media:description: A thick layer of smog covered Connaught Place, in the heart of New Delhi, on Saturday.
item.description: Levels of the most dangerous particles soared over the weekend in some places to more than 16 times the limit India’s government considers safe.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Hong Kong Elected 2 Separatists. China Took Drastic Action.
item.media:description: Sixtus Leung, left, and Yau Wai-ching at a protest in Hong Kong on Sunday. The two lawmakers are at the forefront of independence efforts in Hong Kong.
item.description: By acting against two dissident lawmakers, Beijing is asserting an authority to set policy in the territory, challenging its semiautonomous status.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Beijing’s Intervention in Hong Kong Election Could Face a Hurdle: Local Courts
item.media:description: Hundreds of Hong Kong lawyers on Tuesday protested China’s move to effectively rewrite a clause in Hong Kong’s charter in order to prevent two young pro-independence politicians from taking office as legislators.
item.description: The decision to effectively amend the territory’s Basic Law will have to be implemented by judges who are trained to protect civil liberties, not the Communist system.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: On Russian TV, Clinton-Trump Race Merits Wall-to-Wall Coverage
item.media:description: Traditional Russian wooden nesting dolls depicting Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump at a gift shop in Moscow on Tuesday.
item.description: The blanket coverage offered a chance to present the election in the worst possible light, with one commentator saying “what the United States calls ‘democracy’ prompts nothing but disgust.”
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Toblerone Alters Shape of 2 Chocolate Bars, and Fans Are Outraged
item.media:description: Toblerone has shrunk and reconfigured two of its iconic milk-chocolate bars. Its former 170-gram bar, top, which is sold mainly at a British discount retailer, is now 150 grams.
item.description: The maker of the Swiss chocolate has shrunk and reconfigured two milk-chocolate versions, with narrower triangles and a wider gap between peaks.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH OLIVENNES

item.title: A Hint of Alcatraz With 2 Inmates on the Run From London Prison
item.media:description: Two inmates were discovered missing on Monday from the Victorian-era Pentonville Prison.
item.description: In a plan reminiscent of a famed 1962 escape, the men had arranged pillows under sheets to fool the guards, British news outlets reported.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: My Journey Into Aleppo: Watching a Moonscape of War Turn Into a Functioning City
item.media:description: A street in western Aleppo, a side of the city controlled by the Syrian government where many shops are open.
item.description: Video and photos taken by a Times reporter, Anne Barnard, show both scenes of destruction and a seemingly normal city: people just continuing on with their daily lives.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Long Avoided by Tourists, Iran Is Suddenly a Hot Destination
item.media:description: European and Iranian tourists visiting the palace of Darius the Great in the ancient city of Persepolis in Iran in 2014.
item.description: With the nuclear deal and a more welcoming attitude, the country is attracting flocks of visitors, particularly from Europe, and even from the U.S.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Court in Israel Sentences Palestinian Teenager to 12 Years for Stabbings
item.media:description: Ahmad Manasra, center, at a court in Jerusalem on Monday, after he was sentenced to 12 years in prison for a stabbing attack in October last year.
item.description: The defendant and his cousin were seeking revenge against Israelis when they carried out an October 2015 stabbing attack in East Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: What in the World: Canada and Denmark Fight Over Island With Whisky and Schnapps
item.media:description: A Canadian flag raising on Hans Island in 2005, left, and a Danish flag raising in 2002.
item.media:credit: From left: Canadian Department of National Defense, Polfoto
item.description: A spirited dispute has lasted since 1984, with one side leaving a bottle of liquor on Hans Island that is later replaced by the other side with its own bottle.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Hungary’s Lawmakers Reject Plan to Block Resettlement of Refugees
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary, right, in Parliament in Budapest on Tuesday. His plan to block a European Union program to resettle migrants from the Middle East and Africa was rejected by lawmakers.
item.description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban had proposed a constitutional amendment to stop a European Union program that would see the country accept migrants from the Middle East and Africa.
item.dc:creator: BALINT BARDI and PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Prince Harry Denounces Media Coverage of His Girlfriend, Meghan Markle
item.media:description: Prince Harry visiting a London hospital in July. He has criticized the media before, but not in such an angry and formal way.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Matt Dunham/Associated Press
item.description: Queen Elizabeth’s grandson attacked the “racial undertones” in newspaper and social media reports of his relationship with Ms. Markle, an American actress.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Rurik Jutting, British Banker, Convicted of Murdering 2 Women in Hong Kong
item.media:description: Protesters outside a court in Hong Kong on Tuesday, showing support for two Indonesian women, Sumarti Ningsih and Seneng Mujiasih, who were killed in 2014.
item.description: The ruling brings to a close a case that cast a spotlight on social inequality and the excesses of the financial sector in one of Asia’s richest cities.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Philippines Can Give Hero’s Burial to Ferdinand Marcos, High Court Rules
item.media:description: Supporters of Ferdinand E. Marcos at the Supreme Court in Manila after the ruling on Tuesday. Against the wishes of rights groups, the court decided there was no basis for barring a hero’s burial for Mr. Marcos.
item.description: The decision clears the way to bury the dictator in a heroes’ cemetery. Rights groups saw it as part of an effort to whitewash an ugly period of history.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Yarchen Gar Journal: High on Tibetan Plateau, Buddhist Spirituality Soars
item.media:description: A Buddhist monk looking out on the Yarchen Gar nunnery in China, where thousands of nuns live in makeshift huts.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: Crowded into ramshackle homes on a remote peninsula at the bend of a river is one of the largest communities of nuns in the world.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Weakened South Korean President Allows Parliament to Pick Prime Minister
item.media:description: Opposition party lawmakers held signs reading “President Park Geun-hye Step Down” as the president arrived at the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, on Tuesday.
item.description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea, in an effort to defuse an influence-peddling scandal, has asked rival political parties to recommend a new prime minister.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Estonia’s Government Teeters on Verge of Collapse
item.media:description: Prime Minister Taavi Roivas of Estonia in June in Brussels.
item.description: Two of three parties governing the small Baltic nation have broken off their coalition agreement, leaving Prime Minister Taavi Roivas exposed to a vote of no confidence in the country’s Parliament.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD MARTYN-HEMPHILL

item.title: Cyprus: Why One of the World’s Most Intractable Conflicts Continues
item.media:description: A Turkish tank in Nicosia, Cyprus, in 1974 after Turkey, fearing a Cypriot union with Greece, invaded to protect Turkish Cypriots.
item.description: The island nation has been divided since 1974 in a complex dispute. Leaders of both sides began five days of talks on Monday to resolve it.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Saving Refugees on the Mediterranean: a Luxury Yacht With a New Purpose
item.media:description: Crew members aboard the Astral searched for boats in distress off Libya.
item.description: Since it started its mission last May, the Astral has helped rescue about 15,000 refugees trying to reach Europe by boat, mostly from Libya.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Sailing Couple Seized by Somali Pirates in 2008 Are Apparently Abducted Off Philippines
item.media:description: The Philippine authorities recovering the Rockall on Sunday in the country’s south.
item.description: The German couple, who were held by Somali pirates in 2008, were said to have been abducted by Abu Sayyaf, an insurgent group.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Hopes for U.K. Trade Deal With India Hit a Snag: Immigration
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India at Hyderabad House on Monday in New Delhi.
item.description: Prime Minister Theresa May has received a rocky reception on a visit to India that was billed as a test of Britain’s ability to prosper outside the European Union.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Trilobites: When Bats Look for Meals Near Wind Power, Bats Die
item.media:description: Wind turbines near Stirling Castle, Scotland.
item.description: A study of turbines in Britain found that each one killed one to two bats each month, with some killing more than 60.
item.dc:creator: JOHN SCHWARTZ

item.title: Mikheil Saakashvili Resigns Post in Ukraine, Citing Corruption
item.description: The former president of Georgia quit his post as governor of the Odessa region, accusing the Ukrainian president of blocking efforts to root out graft.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Florence Journal: 50 Years After a Devastating Flood, Fears That Florence Remains Vulnerable
item.media:description: Floodwaters rushed through the square in front of the Basilica of Santa Croce in Florence after the River Arno overflowed in November 1966.
item.description: As the “mud angels” who helped rescue art and rare books returned to Florence on the 50th anniversary of the flood, some worried about future disasters.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Australia’s Parliament Rejects Public Vote on Gay Marriage
item.media:description: A rally in support of same-sex marriage in Sydney, Australia, in June.
item.description: Many of those who opposed the nonbinding plebiscite said it would be a platform for hate speech. Instead, they want lawmakers to decide the issue directly.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: A Slow Ride Toward the Future of Public Transportation
item.media:description: A self-driving bus in Helsinki, Finland, which has been at the forefront of efforts to use technology to rethink public transportation.
item.media:credit: Ugri Touko Tapani Hujanen for The New York Times
item.description: A self-driving bus being tested in Finland holds promise for reducing cities’ dependence on cars.
item.dc:creator: HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: After These Days of Rage
item.description: Extremes of inequality lie at the root of voters’ anger. We can’t repair the political center without fixing the economics of that.
item.dc:creator: ALAN JOHNSON

item.title: Editorial: Nicaragua’s Electoral Farce
item.description: President Daniel Ortega won a third term in a rigged vote, setting the stage for a dynastic dictatorship.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The U.S. Must Extradite My Grandfather’s Killer
item.media:description: Sheikh Mujibur Rahman speaks at a news conference in Dhaka, Bangladesh, in 1972.
item.description: America should stop sheltering an assassin of Bangladesh’s first president and allow justice to be done at long last.
item.dc:creator: SAJEEB WAZED

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
